g.text: The diagnostic role of miR-122 in drug-induced
Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) is a potentially severe adverse drug reaction especially in susceptible patients. But
there are no sensitive or speci
c parameters to detecting DILI. The speci
c expression of miR-122 in the liver has been a hotspot in
the evaluation of hepatic toxicity due to its high stability and sensitivity.
We performed a systematic literature review through July 31, 2017 to identify studies which evolved DILI patients testing
miR-122 without limiting a certain drug. According to the PRISMA statement, a meta-analysis: the diagnostic role of miR-122 in DILI
was made. QUADAS-2 quality evaluation table was used to evaluate the quality of the documentary evidence, PRISMA
quality evaluation table were drawn with RevMan, use Stata to calculate the sensitivity and speci
city of miR-122 in diagnosing DILI,
ROC curve and Deeks funnel plot were also drawn by STATA.
Eleven studies involved 194 DILI patients and 251 controls, all were tested miR-122 (fold change). Sensitivity of miR-122 in
0.97). While in acetaminophen (APAP)-induced liver injury, the sensitivity was [0.82 (95%
In this systematic review and meta-analysis, we found miR-122 have a high speci
city in DILI, and a modest positive
diagnostic effects. On the basis of the limited evidence, further research is needed to evaluate the long-term observation and more
clinical data to testify miR-122 in diagnosing DILI.
area under the ROC curve, DILI
preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and Meta-analyses, QUADAS-2
paired receiver operating characteristic curve, RUCAM
diagnostic biomarker, drug-induced liver injury, miR-122
Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) is a commonly encountered
disease in those years. Although it accounts for
liver injury cases, it is the most common reason lead to acute liver
failure (ALF) in the United States and Europe.
DILI, with more than half of the cases need liver transplanta-
Overall surveys in France and Iceland showed that DILI
occurs with an annual incidence of about 14 to 19 per 100,000
In China, only 50.65% DILI patients cured but
Also, DILI is one of the potentially severe adverse
drug reactions (ADR) which are a major concern for healthcare
systems and pharmaceutical industry, with a cost of £1 billion in
United Kingdom and $4 billion in the United States.
Lacking of the objective diagnostic criteria, DILI is often
diagnosed after exclusion from other diseases, causality scores
such as the Roussel-Uclaf Causality Assessment Method
rm or exclude the suspicion of
But limitations of such scoring algorithms are poor inter-
rater reliability and arbitrary scoring, for example, for alcohol
During rule out diseases one by one, it may already lead to
irreversible liver damage even ALF. New emerging biomarkers
could be useful in diagnosing DILI include total keratin18 (K18),
caspase-cleaved keratin18 (ccK18), high mobility group box 1
(HMGB1) and microRNA-122 (miR-122),but there are still no
diverse biological responses and are expressed in various cell
Some miR species demonstrate high tissue
where it accounts for 70% of the total miRNA content found in
the liver, making it potentially an ideal candidate as a DILI
And it has been shown to be a more sensitive and
c biomarker for liver toxicity when compared with
standard protein biomarkers used to date.
While important for clinical decision-making, little is known
about the overall and comparative diagnosing role of miR-122 in
DILI patients. To address this knowledge gap, we conducted a
YL and PL contributed equally to this work.
